summary: Email correspondence between defense attorney Laura Menninger and a federal prosecutor regarding discovery issues in the US v. Maxwell case. The emails discuss logistical arrangements for reviewing evidence (hard drives, boots, photos), discrepancies in the count of 'Highly Confidential' images, problems with viewing discovery materials, and the de-designation process for sensitive materials.

events.title: Scheduled Trial Date
events.description: The trial date for US v. Maxwell is set for November 29, 2021, mentioned in the context of discovery deadlines.

events.title: Evidence Review in New York
events.description: Defense counsel traveled to New York to review evidence, including highly confidential materials on hard drives, but encountered technical problems.

events.title: FBI Report on HC Materials
events.description: An FBI report dated January 27, 2021, indicated approximately 33,747 highly confidential images and 895 videos from CART-processed evidence, creating a discrepancy with earlier verbal estimates.

locations: Denver, CO 80203 (Haddon, Morgan & Foreman, P.C. office)
New York, NY 10007 (Southern District of New York U.S. Attorney's Office)
Colorado (FBI field office where evidence review is proposed)
New York (Epstein's residence, source of seized CDs)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell is held)
keyFacts: A significant discrepancy exists in the count of 'Highly Confidential' (HC) images: initially verbally estimated at ~2,100 from Epstein's devices, but an FBI report indicated ~33,747 HC images and 895 HC videos.
The FBI was in the process of de-designating HC materials (changing classification from Highly Confidential to Confidential) for images that do not depict genitals, breasts, or buttocks.
Evidence to be reviewed includes hard drives containing images from CDs seized from Epstein's New York residence (~40,000 images) and from Epstein's devices, as well as physical evidence like boots.
The defense reported widespread problems viewing discovery, including corrupt files, missing metadata, unreadable file formats, and difficulties accessing materials at the detention center.
The correspondence shows active negotiation over where and how the defense can review sensitive evidence, with proposals to transfer materials to Colorado for review.
